reviewText: Postal 2 is exactly what you make of it. Yes, it can be a gruesome, unsavory, albeit cartoony, experience, and the game does push you to that end most of the time, but it can also be a open world game that allows you to explore a satirical world filled with both hilarious situations and expectations that speak volumes about paranoid, and in many ways complacent, mid-2000s America. In many ways, it shows how trivial the concerns of the time actually were in the grand scheme of things. Postal 2 needs to be given more credit for pushing the envelope for games; what was once considered taboo was torn apart and amplified in this game. Wholly recommended as an experience.

reviewText: The prequel to Animal Crossing (Orig. Doubutsu no Mori, released in 2001 for the Nintendo 64), Postal 2 is an experimental first look at how Animal Crossing would eventually expand. Explore a large, bustling town where each NPC has their own schedule, and you can perform menial-but-fun tasks in any way you wish.\n\nFeaturing many food items, as well as the ability to use the signature 'shovel' item from Animal Crossing, this game has endless possibility for fun. Spend hours gathering all of certain kinds of items, just to say that you did! Fans of Animal Crossing will not be disappointed - I give this game an 11 out of Shigeru Miyamoto.

reviewText:
Do you like Postal 2? The first game was a little too Columbine for my tastes, but when Postal 2 came out in '03, I think the series really came into its own, commercially and artistically. The whole game has a clear, crisp level of violence, and a new sheen of consumerate decadence that really gives the mindlessness a big boost. It's been compared to Manhunt, but I think Postal has a far more sarcastic, cynical sense of humor.

In '04, RWS released this, Apocalypse Weekend, their most insane content addon. I think their undisputed addition from this was the destruciton of Paradise, an ending so gratifying, most people don't pay attention to the message. But they should, because it's not just about the pleasures of destroying and moving on, and the importance of the post-Cold War era, it's also a personal statement about how Vince feels about the Middle East in general.

HEY PAUL

reviewText:
Leave any reservations at the door before playing Postal 2 and you're in for a good time. Cut people to pieces, light them on fire then urinate on them to exinguish the flames or stick a cat on the end of a shotgun and fire away. Or don't do any of this and just be a nice, normal citizen.

In this game you're The Dude, going around doing things like collecting milk and a paycheck, but something always manages to go horribly wrong and you're forced to murder everyone in your near vicinity. It's like a poor man's Grand Theft Auto, without the driving, constant cinematics and only mimimal social commentary.

Damn good fun for anyone who doesn't have a stick up their butt and the expansion packs and recent DLC are all great also.

reviewText:
Postal 2.
One of the best games I have ever played in my life.
I mean it serious. I know this game for many years already and played definitely over 300 hours in it (DVD Version). And now it came to Steam. This is the best thing that could have ever happened to it. I updated this dated review a bit for higher quality standards and updated informations.
Also make sure to check out my little bit shorter Paradise Lost review.

Its amazing how much work and heart the developers put into this game.
It still gets updates after 12 years of the actual release. Probably the longest supported game in history? Actually it wasnt updated for several years to be honest. It was actually quite around Postal for many years. Not even Postal 3 changed this fact, especially because it wasnt as good as the most people wanted it to be. It wasnt developed by RWS anyway. I think this game was ok but couldnt reach Postal 2 in any way.
I personally do not recommend Postal 3 because its buggy and glitchy as hell.
Maybe wait for some proper patches/mods one day...

Now to the actual game review.
In Postal 2 you play as The Postal Dude. One of my favorite game characters of all time. A man living with his wife in a motorhome in the city Paradise.
You have to do normal things like buying stuff in the store or returning books to the mall. Or getting a christmas tree. Those sort of tasks you have to finish to progress in the game.
But this isnt often as easy as we would wish. The crazy city Paradise comes always into our ways. The police, protestors, priests, god*amn even Osama wants us dead. But we can defend ourself and attack back with several weapons. One of the biggest weapon collections ever seen in a game. This Steam versions has even more than the old DVD version. A lot of AWP and ED weapons has been added. Not all but many which doubles the fun. Pistols, shotgun, scissors to rocket launchers. We can also pee on everyone and everything. It was never easier to take a p*ss. Also the gore has been raised extremely. Now you have the same gore amount that was included in the addon Apocalypse Weekend, which is btw included. We can also grab our dog or cat to fight against the citizens but cats are mostly just useful to silence your guns. No, I'm not kidding. There are also other items ingame like health pipes". Yeah
date: you know what I mean. In addition to that there are a lot of secrets and goodies ingame! The game is actually open world but with several levels that are only visitable to certain days. Yes the game has days. Monday to Sunday actually. The standard Postal 2 was Monday to Friday but the addon added Saturday and Sunday. You can play Monday to Friday or Saturday and Sunday or the whole week. Everything is possible when you start a new game. Oh and because we came to the start a new game part. There are so many difficulties! I cant remember such a big difficulty amount in any other game. No clue how many exactly there are but definitely over 10! Every of those difficulties offers a different game experience. From the people who hit you with shovels to people who shoot with rocket launchers at you and who are insulted already when you look at them. There is everything. I think that should be enough about the game itself.\n\nThe game also has a multiplayer but I think most here wont care for it anyway
recommended: its not much played.\nIts not horrible but kinda outdated
hoursPlayed:
but no wonder. There are still sometimes a few players to find.

The game itself runs with the Unreal Engine 1.5 or 2 when im right. Some hybrid of it.
So it means that this game is dated. If you await nice fancy graphics
voteText:
you are at the wrong address.
But the engine does what is should. It has also been updated with the latest patches released on Steam. Before Steam it was kinda unstable and crashed often. This problems are by now fixed.
Also Steamworks has been integrated. Also archievements and trading cards. Workshop exists now too. So everything that a actual game needs right?
But there are so many fixes and changes by now
helpfulPercent:
that I cant even say them all.
Best to check out the store page. Incredible work by the devs!

Well

reviewText:
Crass & silly // Recommended for those who enjoy mindless mayhem
+ Tons of mod support
+ User has complete freedom in regards to how tasks are carried out, and in what order
+ Large, materially rewarding areas to explore
+ Excessively violent, terribly offensive, and often funny in a self-aware fashion
+ Entertaining weapon modifications (e.g. cat suppressor)
+ Decent weapon selection available to the player
+ Includes unzip and urination mechanics; NPCs will even comment on and react to the player's exposure

- Aged visuals and general presentation, including audio and voice-acting
- Frequent and irritating loading screens
- Humor is considerably low-brow, frequently focusing on bodily fluids, etc.
- Hit detection is deplorable
- Excessive required walking to get from one point to another; this is exacerbated by an often baffling level design

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Feel free to also join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText: This is the game that all anti-video game politicians are referring to when they're spewing rhetoric about violent video games, whether they know it or not. POSTAL 2 is a delightful sandbox FPS where the only real goal is to finish your daily To-Do Lists.\n\nNow, you CAN simply walk directly to the supermarket, pick up some milk, pay the cashier, and leave; OR you could slaughter your way there, steal the milk, kill everyone in the building, and then urinate on their corpses - it's 100% up to you. For the most part, the game's tagline is correct: It's only as violent as you are
date:
but there are definitely some parts of the game where you *have* to absolutely kill everything in sight to survive.

Oh also in the Apocalypse Weekend expansion you get to go Gallagher on some mad cows with a sledgehammer - definitely one of the best parts of the game, second only to the Tourettes Zombies.

This is a game that should be in EVERYONE'S library, because it's the perfect game for letting off some steam. ♥♥♥♥♥♥ day at the office? Go blow up some elephants. Proffessor giving you a hard time in class? Set fire to a marching band. About to shoot up your workplace because you just absolutely can't take it anymore? Please don't, and instead take your anger out on hallucinations of mutated, nightmarish Gary Colemans (also, seek therapy).

This game is a bit over 10 years old, but the magnificent mother ♥♥♥♥ers at Running With Scissors are rad enough that they've continued to update it with numerous patches, additional content, workshop support, and achievement support.

9/10 only because 10/10 is reserved for Half Life 3.

Oh and ♥♥♥♥ Uwe Boll.
helpfulPercent: 117 of 137 people (85%) found this review helpful 16 people found this review funny

reviewText: Intentionally ironic and satirical, Postal 2 picks up where its predecessor left off – as a game that, while highly controversial, is loads of fun.If you have a twisted sense of humor, if you hate cats and enjoy South Park, Beavis and Butthead, Jackass or any of those other guilty pleasures then you will certainly find plenty to smile about while exploring Paradise.A nonstop tour de force of insulting insanity. And even though I should be disgusted by the potty humor and derogatory caricatures, I had a blast playing through it. Postal 2 just cries out for multiplayer, particularly when you can lay down a snaking path of gasoline for half a block and light it up; what a way to trap and kill your local or online friends! Alas, it's not there.I can take points away from the game for many things, but none of these things really detract from the fun that you can have with this game. The game is about one thing, and one thing only - fun. And it delivers.

reviewText:
You ever have one of 'those' days?

This is THE violent video game. This game was one of many others that parents all across the United States wanted banned so that their children wouldn't have their eyes spoiled by its horrific imagery. Now you can experience all of its excessive, abhorrent content on Steam.

First of all let me say that this game is a personal favorite of mine. I had played it at a friend's place way back and loved it, but never had a chance to buy it. So when I saw that it was on Greenlight I thought 'Hey, why not?' and gave it an enthusiastic thumbs up. The day it released I bought it, pretty excited to experience it again nearly a decade later. I was not disappointed.

This game has aged considerably well, considering it was made in 2003. However, its age does show.

Pros:
+The gameplay, controls, and combat are tight. Being how old this game is, there was no dime-a-dozen cover mechanics or regenerating health, so strafing, bunny-hopping, and repeatedly crouching up and down behind low cover while firing are some tactics that work. Reloading is for losers and newbies, so feel free to waste all three-hundred shots of your AR15.

+The comedy of this game hasn't lost its humor. Being an over exaggerated parody of life in the United States during 2003, a lot of the jokes made still hold water to this day. Overbearing banks, corrupt priests, trigger-happy cops, stereotypical Islamic terrorists, religious cults, cannibals, ♥♥♥♥-y rednecks, people simply not giving a damn, the whole shebang viewed and commentated from the eyes of a sarcastic cynic just trying to get through a pretty hectic week.

+Techincally, this game is pretty stable and has some interesting features. I haven't seen any game-breaking bugs, but I have had a crash or two. If you ever get stuck somewhere in the world (which is bound to happen considering it's a free-roaming sandbox) the game teleports you to a nearby spot free of charge. There are also some small pieces of unimportant mechanics that are superflorus but fun. Exploring around is rewarded with interesting to downright strange results. Attaching a cat to your barrel to suppress your weapon is a neat but useless feature. Placing a donut on the ground and taking a leak on it will have an interesting outcome. Speaking of which, this game still has the best urine physics I've ever seen in a game... oddly enough.

+A large, open world to explore and wreak havoc in.

+A multiplayer, though I don't know how active it is.

Cons:
-The gameplay feels old. You've probably seen or played a game that had similar combat to this and that may be a downside to you. The gameplay isn't also 'realistic'. So no aiming down the sights or jelly on your face when you get shot.

-The comedy of this game will turn off a lot of people, considering how carebear people have gotten on the internet lately. If you are easily offended by racial stereotypes, large amounts of cursing, ultraviolence, animal abuse, graphic vomitting and urination, homophobia, whatever, then this game is definitely not for you; stick to Gone Home, that will probably be more your speed.

-Quite short, with a very simple story so if you are looking for a 'cinamatic adventure' you should probably look elsewhere.

All in all, I recommend this game if just for a single playthrough. You want a numbered score? 8/10.

I regret nothing.

reviewText:
This game is more than a sandbox game. It's a simulator of a worker who goes postal. That last statement is actually false. You can choose to go through the whole game WITHOUT going postal. So its more of a game of right or wrong.

Other than that lets start the review.

This game is always being updated so don't worry about that. They usually release a update around a holiday such as halloween 2014. In the halloween 2014 update instead of terrorists there are SPOOKY SCARY SKELETONS THAT COME FROM THE GATES OF HELL (and yes I literally mean they come from the gates of hell). With the steam workshop feature there is a infinite amount of things you can do in postal 2.

So this is classified as a open world, fps, sandbox game. If you were to relate this to garry's mod than you're completly wrong. This game is nothing like garry's mod. If you were to relate it GTA you'd still be wrong and besides GTA is third person anyway :special:. Postal 2 is its own kind of game. It's one of a kind and there will truely be nothing like this for decades to come. Hell, Postal 3 couldn't even compete with Postal 2. I'd say the closest a game got to postal 2 would be goat simulator. It goes on the same principle as postal 2. You can choose to act like a normal goat or go around rampaging the city. See how the two are alike? But, still, the two games are completly different.

Who said you going postal was a bad thing? You can go and destroy terrorist organizations, Protest/deal with protesters, etc. Or you can go on a rampage with cat silencers and bombs and gasoline. That works too.

I would reccomend you to buy this game ASAP. It's worth every penny.

reviewText:
Game name: Postal 2
Game score: 9.5/10
Reviewed by: Wolf

In Summary...Postal 2 is the successor to the contraversial series, Postal, which hit the stores on April 12, 2003. The story features The Postal Dude, or just Dude for short, and his adventures across the week doing various errands. Things more than often turn hasty, leaving a simple chore of picking up milk" into slaying some Al-Queda members. Each day features a list of 3-4 errands to run
date: across all 5 days of the week (and 2 in the "Apocalypse Weekend" mode). The DLC
hoursPlayed: features almost the same layout: 5 days of errands
voteText: but no weekend. All in all
helpfulPercent: it's quite a different experience

reviewText:
It breaks all the rules, it aims an enormous pi$$-take towards celebrities and groups/cultures, its secretly the game we all love to play.

Paradise Lost takes place a decade after Apocalypse Weekend, the Postal Dude awakens from his 11-year radioactive-induced coma only to find his dog Champ is missing and has to go back to his home town of Paradise, which is now a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Paradise Lost also retcons Postal III as it was revealed that the events of that game were just a nightmare dream that the Postal Dude had during his coma. Thankyou devs, for understanding just how bad Postal 3 was!

Expect familiar humour and circumstances in this wonderful, entertaining expansion. Its been a long time Postal, we've missed you.

EDIT: Also as a sidenote, this game has the best set of achievements I've ever seen in a game. There are so many references inside them, definitely worth checking them out. For example, Fear and Loathing" for smoking 10 health pipes and 10 tins of catnip in one play session
date: and "Finkle IS Einhorn!" Gave a kickoff to a severed head (Ace Ventura reference). Very well done."

reviewText:
One of the most bizarre and controversial titles of the early 2000s is back and it’s found its way onto STEAM. Postal 2 Complete has been greenlit by the community, which either means that its now better than ever or that we’ve all completely lost our minds.

After playing the game again, it would seem as though the latter is true.

In Postal 2, you are given a number of errands that you must complete each day. While the errands are similar to what most of us would call “missions”, their objectives are often much more simple than the missions we’ve become accustomed to in RPGs and other titles. In a testament to this, one of the first errands you have to run is to go to the store and get some milk. The atmosphere of the store is hilarious, as the middle eastern music blasts and the shopkeeper insults all of the patrons in his shop. The brilliance of Postal 2 is the non-linear manner in which you can complete your errands. Do you just pay for the milk or do you just grab it and then fight your way out of the store, hitting everyone in your path with a shovel? The choice is yours. I should warn you though, the shop keeper is packing serious heat.

reviewText: The most artistic indie game I've ever played. In Postal 2, you must resist the urge to be a terrible person in a world that mirror's our own. Guns are everywhere in Arizona, and everyone carries them because of the damned Republicans and their concealed carry laws. The game shows you what can go wrong in such a society, as things get progressively worse every day.\n\nIt's also a pretty good simulation of life. You can pee in the toilets, (can't flush them though, no use key). You can collect stray cats and deposit them in safe places, You can also find tanks of gasoline and fuel up people's cars. Neat! You can do almost anything your imagination can think of!

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone, I will be honest. Most people will either love it to death or hate it with the passion of a super nova.

Imagine the world of Grand Theft Auto San Andreas without the use of cars. Now combine this with the psychotic NPCs, weapon/item gathering, and combat mechanics of Dead Rising (only in 1st person). Sprinkle in enough political incorrectness to challenge South Park and you have Postal 2.

If that description sounds good to you, this is probably a must play for you. If it sounded terrible, you have been warned.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying Postal 2 will let you knock off someone's head, and urinate down the stump.

Still interested? Good.

Postal 2 is, at it's heart, a game for everyone, that anyone can relate to. You play as a guy who has errands to run throughout the week. How you get those errands done is up to you, but that's only part of the game - the other is, trying to get those errands done while surrounded by dim-witted, poorly dressed psychopaths.

What will you do when you get your milk? Pay 5 bucks for a quart, or just walk out with it? Maybe set the place on fire? Maybe set EVERYTHING on fire? Smack people with a shovel to get to the front of the line? Pee in their eye? Drop a diseased cow head, causing everyone in its vicinity to hemorrhage blood from every orifice until they die, while the screaming survivors run out the door, only to be met by a carefully laid booby trap of grenades, blowing them apart in all directions? Maybe borrow" a police uniform beforehand

...not that I've ever done that.

reviewText: Aah... Postal 2. I really do love this game. A game I can play time after time after time over the years since it was launched (and I have), and it NEVER gets old. It remains a title that I feel compelled every once in a while to go back to and play right the way through. It's a game that is a testament to the power of good writing with a sense of the anarchic and absurd, which combine to turn acts of extreme violence (that would otherwise leave a nasty taste in the mouth) into a series of dark comedy vignettes. RWS rock.\n\nDone and done.

reviewText:
Review: POSTAL 2
What is it?POSTAL 2 is many things. First and foremost, it's a FPS (First Person Shooter), it can also be considered a Comedy (which is actually surprising, considering the first game was very dark in spirit, with little humor to be found), but it's also an adventure game (though, it has little story) with a major focus on exploration. Players spend 5 days (or, a week if you're playing the expansion pack, too) as the Postal Dude, a simple guy living in the small town of Paradise, Arizona, even though it's far from that. From here, you're given tasks to do throughout the day, with unpredictable, and often times quirky outcomes.

The High Points (pros)POSTAL 2 is a violent game, to an extent where the developers literally have a warning about the violence BEFORE the game starts up. However, the violence isn't gimmicky here. It's over-the-top, and somewhat works. However, if you are disturbed by Blood and Gore in games, you can beat POSTAL 2 without killing anyone, which is tough if you aren't stockpiling the health items, one of which takes some of your health away after a while. This game also has ALLOT of achievements that are more than just 'Kill X People', and actually encourage you to replay the game a bit. However, the best thing about POSTAL 2 by far is just how atmospheric it is. Sure, the graphics may not have dated all too well, but, the map on display here is MASSIVE, and only locked up by little loading segments. Another thing: this game is REALLY funny! The One-Liners spouted by our anti-hero (or, plain villain if you play it like that) are original (though, I'll get to that in a bit), and allot of other things can be considered as hilarous, too... just, don't expect gut-busting laughs all the way through. To finish this off, this game is full of odd tasks and strange situations. Of course, I won't spoil these situations, because they need to be experienced first-hand.

Summary:
-HUGE map
-Very atmospheric
-Multiple playstyles
-Incredibly funny
-Brilliant achievements that require exploration, and give the game replayability.
-Over-the-top violence that supports the games tone in a strange way

The Low Points (cons)I really don't have much to say here.
Sure the graphics are dated, but you need to remember: this game is OLD.
I think my largest flaw with this game are the reptitive one-liners. Are they funny? YES! But, chances are, you'll hear them multiple times throughout the game, to an absurd extent. The objectives are also kinda spread out a bit far, but, not too much to actually be a problem.

Summary:
-Repeating One-Liners

IN CONCLUSION (verdict)POSTAL 2 is a quirky game, and I love it, especially after replaying it. It's atmosphere and large map add to the experience, as well as multiple playstyles allowed. It's a funny game for sure, starring an oddly memorable anti-hero, and unusual events that sorround him every day. It also encourages replayability with clever achievements, that go into the realms of exploration at times. Is the game violent and really ♥♥♥♥ing offensive? Yes, but to an extent that works. On a critical landscape, this game is far from perfect, but that doesn't mean it's not a damn fine game, which it is.
And, yes, don't buy this if you're easily offended, because it's clearly not made for you.

FINAL GRADE: A-

reviewText:
Basic Information
Title: POSTAL 2
Genre: Action, Adventure, Indie
Developer: Running With Scissors
Publisher: Running With Scissors
Release Date: 13 Apr, 2003

General Impression
POSTAL 2 is an adventurous game, mostly fitting to people who enjoy violent games. The graphics for 2003 are spectacular, the soundtrack are enjoyable, the atmosphere varies from outside to buildings and houses in the city called Paradise, AZ (in the USA). The gameplay is an open-world type, having the ability to do whatever you want, such as walking through the town, killing civilians/gangsters/police, beating animals, urinating on anything you want, a pretty rebel gameplay. The story is about a Postal Dude which just moved to Paradise, AZ with his wife, and his dog, Champ. He will have to go through 7 days (from Monday to Sunday) where he will have to accomplish many risky takes, which mostly have unwanted consequences. The engines are well optimized, very rare crashes, and generally good engines.

Graphics
The graphics are spectacular for the year 2003, being a huge improvement over the first POSTAL game, by bringing the three dimensions feature and brining in the First-Person and the Third-Person. This game can be run even on low performance computers, which would still be able to run this game on Medium-High. The sky is mostly blue-yellowish, nights are very rare in this game, the cars, the guns, the buildings, and the nature things are well designed. Humans are being randomly deployed, being pretty well designed too. The buildings and houses are also well designed, giving more reality to Paraside.

Atmosphere
The atmosphere varies from being outside to the ability to walk in every single building or house of this game, being a huge advantage for explorers. We may also see desert, because it’s located in Arizona. In the south of the town we may see higher altitudes, which also contain some forests. The game mostly happens during the daytime, very rare during the night time. We may see people everywhere, even animals, cats can be attached on shotguns, which seems pretty funny. There are many places to visit, also the DLC expands the areas even more (underground areas and even a new Paradise, a terrorized one. The population is very scared due to the atomic explosion which happened years back then.

Audio
The soundtrack of this game were composed by RWS, proving that the developer has truly put effort in making a completely original game. During fights, we may hear some dynamic soundtracks, which encourages you to fight even better. While doing missions or just exploring the city, no soundtracks will play. We may hear birds singing, people talking, and sometimes the wind. We may also hear animals, such as dogs chasing cats, etc. The sound of the bullets are pretty alright, the voice acting is also very nice, especially for the Postal Dude.

Gameplay
The gameplay is about the Postal Dude who does many tasks for his wife, such as buying milk, returning an overdue library book, getting Gary Coleman’s autograph, etc. This game is Open-World too, you may walk everywhere, and you can do what you want, anytime. You can even buy pizzas, donuts, drinks, etc. Also, there are some vending machines which sell heal kits, drugs (for health), etc.  (the health vending machine) and guns, grenades, vests, etc. (the weapons vending machine).  You can also talk with people (only the ones which have connections with missions). Overall good gameplay.

Story
The story Is about a Postal Dude which just moved in Paradise, AZ with his wife and his dog, Champ. He has to go through many adventures, among tasks given by his wife.  He needs to buy milk, steak pay his debts, return overdue books, and pretty much everything about violence/killing. After Friday, his wife will shot him in the head, causing him a tumor. In the next 2 days, he will make his way out of Paradise. In the new DLC, the Postal Dude came back In Paradise, but most of the town was already terrorized by the past atomic bomb, detonated by the Postal Dude himself. He will have to deal with many nations, such as Arabs, the Coleman family, etc.  The difficulties are way too many, nobody would need to choose from that many.

Engines
The engines on this game are well optimized, almost no crashes or bugs. The people's movements are pretty good, starting from walking calm through the town to running due to being alerted. The sky does not move, but in the DLC we may find snowing. In the cities there are cars which stand on the edge of the road or in garages, however, none of them is ever moving. When you shoot down somebody to death, I feel like their falling is not realistic. They just simply fall, not like in reality.  Also, I did not like how the sand is behaving. Instead of flowing in the air, it simply stays on the ground. This game can be played even on low performance computers, which give it a huge advantage.

Strong PointsWell designed graphics for 2003
Almost no bugs or crashes
Nice sounds and soundtrack
Awesome voice acting
Well optimized engines
Good and coordinated AI
Big city to explore
Great sense of humor
Many weapons to choose from
Open-World game
Good DLC and soundtrack
Long storyline
Weak PointsFrequent loading zones
Too many difficulties to choose from
You get stuck too fast in random objects
You can’t drive any cars, the biggest disadvantage
General Ratings (because this game is getting old, I must give it some ratings for the releasing year)
Graphics: 10/10
Atmosphere: 10/10
Audio: 10/10
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Story: 10/10
Engines: 9.5/10

Personal Rating: 9.83/10

General Ratings
Graphics: 8.5/10
Atmosphere: 9/10
Audio: 9/10
Gameplay: 8.5/10
Story: 10/10
Engines: 8/10

Personal Rating: 8.83/10

reviewText:
There is a lot that can be said about Postal 2. It is obscene enough to be banned in Germany, New Zealand, Australia and a few other countries when it first released one decade ago. As a result, eviewer scores, fueled by moral panic, really dealt a blow to its overall score the first time around. Which is why it is a very good thing that this game got a new re-release on Steam 10 years later, because this game is a real hidden gem that deserves a lot more credit than it got.

This game, in its original form, is a sandbox shooter with a lot of offensive and crude humor. It is set in the ironically-named fictional town of Paradise, populated by jerks. Players take on the role of some down-on-his-luck everyman, living on a trailer and about to be laid off. His task is to survive the week by taking on various errands. This seems mundane and uninteresting on the surface, however, littered around the town are tools that let the player cause mayhem and destruction, as well as extremeist and special interest groups that are hell bent on killing the player dead. Not only that, but at various points, events happen that put the player in situations that they must come out of alive.

Then, we have the Steam edition of the game, which adds a ton of new extra content, as well as canonizing one of the more popular mods for the game as part of the package. This mod introduces even more enemy types for you to blow up, as well a couple new toys to play with. This mod also offers a more linear mission structure, which provides an interesting contrast to the type of gameplay present in the original game.

On top of that, there is a third campaign which combines both the original game and the content of the mod into seven whole days of mayhem. There is even a hidden unlock that players can get if they beat this third combined campaign in the very hard POSTAL difficulty mode.

What makes these single player experiences so compelling is the inclusion of choice for the player. They have the ability to choose whether they want to survive the errands peacefully, or if they would like to do so causing as much mayhem as possible. They have a vast potential arsenal of weapons and toys that they can pick up and cause mayhem with. Not only that, a lot of the crude and offensive humor is put there as a biting commentary of the then (and possibly now) fast-food culture and excesses of contemporary western culture. Gameplay-wise, I also like how the wanted system is set up so that your wanted meter only goes up when committing a crime in the proximity of law enforcement.

This game also includes a multiplayer portion (Share the Pain) for deathmatch mayhem, and all things considered, it would have been a really fun experience, if the netcode was better. Which is a shame, because that means that having a lag-free experience entails getting all your friends together for a LAN party, which isn't exactly viable if all your friends are spread across the world. There is also the minor issue of game stability and intermittent crashes, however this shouldn't be too much of a problem with the smart use of saves.

In short, I would highly recommend that you pick up this game, there is no question about it, as its normal selling price is $9.99 which is a steal for a game with this amount of potential enjoyment. And if this isn't a good enough deal for you, this game now has workshop support, which gives you the option of downloading and playing through a plethora of well-made user content.

Well this game is basically the most fun I have had in games for years, and let me tell you why in pros and cons

PROS:

The Postal Dude!: You are the Postal Dude, and what do you do? Go postal! The whole point of the game is to cause mayhem and have fun with it, plus he makes alot of funny quips and they are even fun to hear over and over again.

The Town: You live in Paradise Arizona, how ironic the name is since the place is full of idiots, gun toting idiots, or bomb toting idiots, but that's the best part about it.

Characters: The characters you meet are just so funny and rude that it's hard to find anything bad about them, they are all hilarious.

Guns: The guns in this game are so much fun to use, even though you have absolutely no reload, I don't see how a m16 can carry 400 bullets in the clip but I ain't complainin.

Peeing on people: Yes, you can do this, you can urinate on somebody till they vomit or just to be a a$$ to them.

Dogs and cats: You can use the dogs are friends! They fight with you! And as for the cats...well...you basically put the barrell of your gun up their a$$ and guess what you have? A Kitty Silencer!

Gore: This game is very very gorey, blood, chopped limbs, guts everywhere, decapitation, it's fun!

Exploring: There are guns and ammo lying all over the place, as well as melee weapons you can find rummaging around, and each day most of the weapons change and won't be there, but new weapons will be in other places.

The Errands: Each day you have errands to do, get milk, go to bank, etc. but the fun part about this game is it doesn't feel like a boring old errand, you actually do something in it, for the bank when you go there you can wait in line or Pee on everyone to get out of the way so you can go first.

Quotes and Easter Eggs: Easter Eggs are hidden throughout the game, as well as the achievements, the one I seemed to notice in a instant was the Bates Hotel with Murder free showers"

The civilians: The civilians are just all around hilarious

reviewText: You know those stupid overhyped news stories about how violent video games are negatively affecting today’s youth? This is exactly the kind of game that they’re afraid of. However, if you have any common sense (and a sense of humor) it’s pretty clear that Postal 2 is simply a satire of American paranoia and ignorance. You play as the Postal Dude, aiding him as he completes a list of tasks over the course of a week. As you go about your business, you’ll notice increasingly crazy things happening all around you, such as anti-violent video game protestors who seem to love trying to kill you, trigger-happy police officers, hillbillies who apparently love the movie “Deliverance”, and more. It’s all very ridiculous and over the top, but that’s exactly the point.\n\nPostal 2 is crude, extremely violent, outrageous, and lots of fun. Avoid if you’re easily offended. Otherwise, go postal.

reviewText:
Surprisingly fun for a 10 year old title. Didn't expect much from it getting it for $0.99 but this is a great game that still holds up. You're let loose upon the politically incorrect, offensive, and amusing world of POSTAL. Given objectives to complete each day (level), you can go about the game as a normal person, but who the hell wants to do that. Lines taking too long? People getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because you walk by them? Pull out your shotgun and blow their heads off. Combat is SO SATISFYING. It's great for blowing off some steam decapitating people with hedge clippers, dousing them in gasoline and lighting them on fire, and urinating on someone until they vomit. Some may call it immature or that you have issues, but this is a hell of a game. Satisfying, BRUTAL, combat.

It also has some of the best achievements out there. They're aren't too grindy and are actually very fun to get. Lure a cop with a ♥♥♥♥ soaked doughnut, play fetch with your dog using a severed head, kill members of the Taliban in a suicide blast, etc.

Due to the open nature of the levels it's pretty replayable and you can lose yourself for hours screwing around.
Worth base price. Definitely worth sale price.

C U Next Tuesday!

reviewText:
There was a time in gaming history when 'worried' politicians and parents were sure that games cause violence. Many of the classics were stomped by suit'n'tie men and women: Quake, Doom, GTA... but one game was known for being the most violent, depraved, senseless depiction of lunacy - POSTAL.

First one was isometric shooter and it introduced us to the concept of senseless violence. We've needed to kill everyone and everything to pass the level. Killing was mandatory, and those enemies were no aliens or demonic creatures - they were all (mostly) innocent humans.

POSTAL 2 arrived sometimes around 2002 or 2003, can't really tell, and it brought the violence into a 3D world. The game went FPS and Postal Dude fans went nuts about it.

Considering that today we have more violent games people play and no one gets mad and there are basically no more politicians, senates, governments and parents deeply worried about what their children play, Postal 2 still stands out as a prime example of total, senseless violence. This game is still 0% politically correct, madness-driven insult toward everyone and everything. It plays nicely on cliches, prejudices and morals - it doesn't give a flying ♥♥♥♥ about religions, races, social, economic or sexual orientations - it's against everyone and everything.

But is it a good shooter? No, it is not. It is full of glitches, bugs and the reason why it stills stands the test of time is the amount of insults its dispersing every time you launch it. If you're a grouchy intellectual, you might find the whole thing tiring and repetitive, but putting people on fire, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on their corpses or in their mouths until the point they vomit, using cats as silencers, chopping off heads with a shovel is still pretty fun, if you're open-minded, clever person knowing it's all bad humor. Yes, in case you ask about my own opinion: violent games can make you go violent only if you're unstable person.

Should you get it?

a) NO, if you're a sensitive person.
b) NO, if you're looking for a decent FPS and you're more interested in game mechanics than idiotic moments of Postal 2.
c) YES, if you're ready to grin, smirk and laugh your ♥♥♥ off at complete lunacy and can get past pretty glitchy shooter.
d) YES, if you've played it back then - getting it for 2 € is like a blast-from-the-past ticket. And game has been improved since then - more voices, more weapons, more characters and Steam achievements, so it's pretty busty. (har-har)

***
If you like this review, feel free to join me for some more recommendations at http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews

reviewText:
In Postal 2, the player takes on the role of the Postal Dude, a tall and thin red-headed man with a goatee, sunglasses, a black leather trench coat, and a t-shirt with a grey alien's face printed on it. Postal Dude lives in a trailer park in the small town of Paradise, Arizona, with his nagging wife, who is identified in the credits as simply, the 'Postal Dude's ♥♥♥♥♥'. The game's levels are split into days of the week starting Monday and finishing Friday.

At the beginning of each day, Postal Dude is given several tasks to accomplish, such as 'get milk', 'confess sins', and other seemingly mundane tasks. The object of Postal 2 is to finish all of the tasks throughout the week, and the player can accomplish these tasks in any way he or she wishes, be it as peaceful and civilly as possible, or as violent and chaotically as possible. It is possible, if occasionally difficult, to complete most tasks without engaging in battle, or at least, harming or killing other characters, as evidenced by the game's tagline: Remember
date: it's only as violent as you are!". The daily tasks can be accomplished in any order the player desires

reviewText:
This is the best game that I have ever played in my life by far.
Here is why:
You are a character who has the freedom to explore. 99% of the buildings, you can enter. The concept of something that seems so common is put into this amazing game. It has hilarious charracters, a nice storyline, appealing graphics, and fun weapons to use. There are so many controls, but once you are good at using it, the game gets so fun. Much like GTA, you are a character who can choose to follow a story or make up one of his own.
Pros
Freedom to roam
Storyline
Graphics
People
Controls
Cons
Map is disorienting, but it is not impossible to figure out.
Health Packages are hard to find, and anyone with a rocket launcher is too overpowered
----------------------------------------
Overall: I would say, no matter the price: get POSTAL 2.
10/10

reviewText:
I am unsure whether I should take this game seriously or not.

And now for the review:
Postal 2 is a game that prides itself in it's deceptively simple story.
On day one, you're only required to pick up milk at the local supermarket, pick up your paycheck, and cash in said paycheck.
And then you realize that doing everything legally is optional.
And then you suddenly find yourself on a crime spree
And then a murder spree
And before you know it, you're killing cops for their equipment like an rpg farmer
And then you wonder: where did I go wrong?

reviewText:
This game is one of the many reasons I'm so ♥♥♥♥ed up, what other game can you chase people around the streets, urinating on them until they throw up, whack their heads off with a spade then p*ss on their severed heads?

Postal 2 at it's base is actually a surprisingly well designed game (if you can refrain from wreaking havoc), giving you an open world with multiple objectives to carry out in any order you please. Postal 2 also has solid, fast paced FPS core mechanics but what it's really notorious for is its messed up humour, everything in this game cracks me up, from the sound of the spade clanging against peoples heads to the many obnoxious references to real life occurences.

The graphics are really impressive keeping in mind that this game is from 2003 as is the level design which gives you lots of areas to explore and tons of secrets to find. Don't expect a Catch(h)er in the Rye" this story is a melting pot of fetus discharge which adds to the hilarity that is bound to offend many people
date: especially people who hate violent video games and Muslims.\n\nI recommend this to people with issues."

reviewText:
One of my favorite games. This game always gives me a great memories for my childhood because i was playing it like 8 years ago.

Game is open world which allows you to free roam. Singleplayer is point of this game. It's so fun and you can do everything what you want. It's pretty long and you have 5 days (7 days with DLC). Every day has 3-4 missions. Missions are fun and crazy so you will totally enjoy while playing. Game also allows yout to play multiplayer mode which is also fun and simple to play with other players or friends on steam.

Developers are still updating and supporting game. Not so long time ago they have released new DLC with brand new edited map and additional missions.

Game is old but still one of the best so far! It is totally worth of money and i reccommend this game to everyone who wanna have some fun.

reviewText: In Postal 2, you play as a middle-aged Postman who delivers packages to a plethora of zany and creative citizens within the town of Postland, including an old magician, an ice cream man (who you have a funny brotherly relationship with) and a very happy missionary who loves to spread the joyful word of God. Chock full of fun puzzles and funny, clean humor, I would reccomend this game to anyone of any age, but this game is especially fun and educational towards ages 10 and under.\n5/5

reviewText:
Despite the game being very dated... and so far has aged very well compared to modern shooters that are... well... copy paste mechanics and gameplay in every single release, this one however is a bit more unique.

I don't know why, but I can't stop the urge to seldomly just kill or shoot someone... just right out of nowhere, boom boom death everywhere. Not sure if that's me releasing my frustration on the world or the side of me that wants the whole world to burn and bathe in their blood like the psychopath I may be. It's up to debate honestly...

Anyway, game's good, can be a massive time waster without even realizing it. It's like watching a train-wreck with explosives and deaths and fires and... more explosives. It's impossible to look away once it starts. You'll be glued to it forever. The weekends are the longest ones, however, than Mon-Fri. I thought Sunday would never end.

I've had a few issues of crashing here and there... not sure what exactly is causing them, but was purely random and at least rare. Too much going on at once?

It's worth the price. Wouldn't wait for a sale. Get it now.

reviewText: My opinionated breakdown review of: POSTAL 2\nGameplay: POSTAL 2 is set in a small town in Arizona named Paradise. You will play as Postal Dude (actual name) completing various day to day activities such as: getting milk, getting autographs from Gary Coleman, retrieving mail, and many other trivial activities that end up turning into an all-out gore fest. You see, this game doesn't care. Anything offensive you can think of, it'll probably be in this game. This game is a sandbox set in first-person based off of the Unreal engine. When you first start playing you will notice how open-ended and interactive the world is. Some sections are cut-off due to plot restrictions but usually, you won't get bored of one area. The combat is fairly dumb, but fun. The game's idea of difficulty is more enemies, and as you progress, you will become rivals with many factions. If I had to describe this game in two words, I would say Murder Simulator." There are many weapons to utilize each with unique effects. Simple things such has scissors can be used as a lethal ninja star immitation. The game is very creative with how you want to kill or torture people (urinating on someone until he/she throws up). Play the game for it's killing
date: not the story.\n\nArt: The game manages to look decent
recommended: even by today's standards. There are a lot of copy and paste areas
hoursPlayed: but each section of the map feels unique enough to grab your attention. You will mostly be looking at blood

votesTotal: other than atmospheric radio. The sound design is decent
votesFunny: most weapons sound like you would expect them to and the screams and remarks of bystanders add to the joy of murdering for no reason.\n\nEntertainment Value: The game is short. It would not be uncommon to beat this game in one day (if you did nothing but missions) but based off of the interaction

reviewText:
I have bought this game on numerous occasions.  From physical media, GOG, and now Steam.  This is an older title so don't expect to be wowed by the fancy graphics.  Besides, if you're reading my review you want 2 things.  Violence and more violence.  This title delivers in spades.  The social commentary is a little dated now, but still relevant for the most part.  You can be as wicked or as sweet as you want.  Being sweet is a challenge.  Being wicked is a blast.

So you enjoy:

1.  Sticking a shotgun up a cat's butt to use it as a silencer?
2.  Urinating on random people?
3.  A firefight VS. Gary Coleman?

Then this just may be the title for you.

This game includes the Apocalypse Weekend and the Share the Pain (MP) add-ons.  The graphics are dated, but it's still a FPS that I like to play.

Finally, DO NOT GET POSTAL 3!  It is an a horrible abomination of a game.  RWS gets no cash from the sale of that piece of ****, as I understand.  I bought that game at retail...   Grrr.....

reviewText:
Postal 2 isn't a particularly polished game, but don't allow that to dissuade you from purchase.

The game is only as violent as you are. It was built entirely around being able to play through it without killing a single person in the game, and being able to disembowl random civilians whilst urinating on them. It is filled with humor and satire and bares a lot of resemblances to what politicians believe all video games are like.

It's a really fun game to play, plus along with the expansions it becomes a fairly lengthy one as well. Definately comes recommended from me.

reviewText:
This game brings a whole new level of offensive, ruthless, and bloody to gaming. In a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ city with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ people, it's up to you if you want to be a good, peaceful, American citizen; or go POSTAL.
This game gives you an immense feeling of freedom and carelessness. It's a funny-♥♥♥ game that lets you do whatever you want, as long as you can handle the heat. There's so many secrets in the map, difficulties, weapons, and locations that it makes achievement hunting a challenge, but a VERY fun challenge. Lots of stereotypes and things to do. Not to mention that the game has aged like a fine wine. Overall, definitely one of my favorite games.

TL;DR: Bloody, repulsive, offensive, and fun.

reviewText: Possibly the greatest game to ever exist in all of time. The 100+ hours that I've spent have all been pure enjoyment (till I completed the Week on POSTAL difficulty, I hated my life at that point.)\n\nThere isn't really anything about this game that I hate. I love just about everything about this game! Keep in mind this game is NEVER to be taken serious. This is a Dark Humor game, and it shows. It pushes the limits like no other game dares to try. Hell most of the achievements have some sort of ♥♥♥♥♥ in the images, or swears. Now coming after Postal 1, which was Kill everything
date:
this game gives you untold amount of options. You can complete the entire game without killing anyone!

The fact they even made a true Expansion for this game 11 YEARS LATER says a lot. The brilliant minds at Running With Scissors are amazing people and LOVE their fans, and they prove that with the Paradise Lost Expansion. Yes I'm calling it an Expansion and not DLC, that is how much content is in it!

Everyone can have their Call of Dudes, Battlefields, Arsarsin's Creeds (Steam censorship), and what ever cash cow big AAA companies produce *cough*  EA, Ubisoft, ♥♥♥♥ Konami  *cough*, or what ever cheap low live scam artist Indi Devs *cough* ImminentUprising *cough*, but I will stick with games that are ♥♥♥♥♥ FUN! Can't wait to see if RWS will make anything else in the future.

reviewText: Postal 2 is dumb as ♥♥♥♥ but in an endearing way. It really helps that the game is total Looney Tunes and doesn't take itself seriously at all. Even the devs poke fun at themselves like for example one of the first things you can do is kill their ingame avatars. The base game is a fun sandbox and the weapons are nice. A neat thing is that you can beat the game non-violently, I did.\n\nMy biggest complaint with the game is that the Apocalypse Weekend expansion sucks ♥♥♥♥. It's a really medicore corridor shooter at best and terrible one at worst and it ends with an absolutely boring boss fight that drags on way too long. It also ♥♥♥♥ed up my otherwise non-violent run. My advice is to not play those missions. The base five days are worth playing alone. Plus they're releasing a new expansion after more than a decade that's going to be more like the vanilla game so that also adds to the recommendation.

reviewText:
Honestly the greatest sandbox fps game in the whole everywhere.


Unlike in Postal where your goal is to just slaughter everything that breathes, Postal 2 sees you living out the life of Postal Dude. All you do is simple errands, and whether or not you want chunks of decapitated human heads sprayed all over the landscape is completely up to you. The game is a FPS, rather than a isometric shooter, and you can do pretty much just about anything imaginable. You can put a cat silencer on your guns, set fire to everything, ♥♥♥♥ on people, or just go on a generic rampage.

But then again, you can also act like a normal person, fulfil your common errands, and not be a general jackass psychopath to everyone around you.

The game's tag line is It's only as violent as you are!". This is one of the most brutally violent games in existence
date: which means its one of the absolute best games in existence."

reviewText:
Postal 2, an old classic brought back to life. A game where a dude goes postal. Oh and his name is Postal Dude, too! What happens when your day goes to ♥♥♥♥? Well, you might tase a dog. Or perhaps shout at people's faces telling them they're going to get killed unless they get to the ground, and yet they stare back at you clueless of how big of a psycho you are. Or perhaps you light some folks of fire, immediately regretting that you did, you try to get the fire out by peeing on them. With the addition of Multiplayer and constant updates(and workshop as well), what could go wrong? Find out for yourselves in this hilariously comical game and unleash your inner psycho.
P.S: If you enjoyed GTA:SA you'll like this, too. And if you're a fan of Postal1/2, Manhunt or similar, check out Hatred on Greenlight.(user discretion is advised). Oh and all the random events that go on... reminds me of Bad Day LA.

>I'd give it a 10/10
>Pros: Despite old it still gets updates, achievements and cards, updated graphics and all, humoristic and dark, violence is optional... but we know you'll do it, fair price.
>Cons: None so far.

reviewText: This game is so much fun! It keeps me laughing through the whole game. I've only played for about an hour so far, but the game definitely has my attention. The controls are a bit confusing in the beginning, but you'll get used to them eventually. There are a few minor glitches here and there, but I'm sure the devs will get working on those asap. The weapons are a bit repetitive as so far I've only been able to use a shovel, pistol, machine gun, and a shotgun. Not sure what the rest of the game holds though. So far, it seems like I'm limitless as to what I can do! I've set someone on fire and haven't even been playing the game for 3 hours!  The achievements and trading cards for this game are pretty funny imo. Navigation is a 10/10 for me, as is the gameplay. This game sorta reminds me of GTA, so if you're a fan of GTA, I definitely recommend this game for you. The blood and gore isn't as intense as I thought it would be, which is a good thing because I don't like too much blood and gore. If you don't like it at all, there is an option to toggle it on and off. So far so good. Can't wait to see what the rest of the game holds! 9/10 Weekend deal so grab it fast!

reviewText:
I never looked into this due to thinking it was just the normal Postal 2 I had on disc still.

But nope they had added achievements, some new voice audio, some updated graphics and to some objects and character models (such as them wearing sun glasses) and added a few new weapons such as knuckle dusters/brass knuckles, A shiv (I think thats what you call it) and from watching the trailer I see there is loads more (Im still early in the game at the moment).

They have also added the weekend add on into the one game, you get a choose from doing all 7 days in the one go, or the default mode of Postal 2 where you play from Monday - Friday. They have also added in a lot of new difficulty options from you to choose from.

There is also updated graphics/video options to set, it supports all 4:3, 16:9 or 16:10 resolutions, which can be all setup before you go into the game or while you have booted up the game.

It also comes bundled with a Single Player and Multiplayer level editior! Also steam cards if your into those!

If you loved Postal 2 STP or had seen the old postal 2 and liked it, I highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
What can I say...the game kicks ♥♥♥...

Yes, it is very controversial...but that is what makes it so damn fun...I mean you can literally do anything...and well those who say it is sluggish or slow in gameplay obviously played it for what may have been like 10 minutes and didnt like all the badass cliche jokes that are in the game...hence they cut it off and came here to make a terrible review on what they experienced...

I can say that if you know sumone insane dont let them play the game unless it helps to prevent them from doing anything bad in real life...

Now those that say this is like GTA...are right yet wrong...it is like GTA in its free roaming way...but GTA isnt as fun or gory or all out let you do anything game...

This game will keep you on the edge of your seat the entire ride...and well yes there is Multiplayer now...and it too is not perfect...it seems that the ingame server browser miscalculates the ping sorta like steam's server browser that you can use before entering a game...so yea...for example it may say that you get like 117 ping on a server but when you join you can really have like half of that...so yea...

The MP also is just as controversial as the SP is so watch out and you have to allow foul language from others to not offend you that much because it is there and will be used...

The graphix people say are not that good but for the Unreal engine they are actually all pretty tight and nice to view...so yea...

Now go and blast away your boss and set the army on fire and well if they run towards you and set you on fire...just pee on your self...but be careful not to ♥♥♥♥ on your self for too long or you may swallow sum...

reviewText:
As an Arizona resident, it's nice to see an open-world game taking place in my home-state! There's tons of cacti, dirt, rude Indian convenience store cashiers, greedy cops, and guns are EVERYWHERE... trust me, this is very accurate!

Now for my review:
There are several modes you can play: A Week in Paradise (AWP), Apocalypse Weekend, and POSTAL 2. Apocalypse Weekend takes place Saturday and Sunday, POSTAL 2 is Monday-Friday, and AWP is all seven days. For each day, you have tasks, such as picking up your paycheck to buy milk, returning a library book, paying a speeding ticket, etc., but there's usually a twist. For example, upon going to the library, you discover violent book protestors. After returning your book, they set the library on fire, and you must work your way to the exit while avoiding the fire. The game presents a fight or flight option: you don't have to attack the protesters, but they are armed and will attack you. Difficulties determine their weaponry: on the easiest difficulty, enemies are armed only with shovels. On higher difficulties, everybody will be armed with handguns, shotguns, and/or assault rifles.

Now, let's talk weapons! You'll find many weapons throughout the game, including the standard layout of handguns, shotguns (including a sawed-off), SMG, assault rifle, sniper, grenades & Molotovs, grenade launcher, and rocket launcher), but you also get tons of other weapons such as a machete than can be thrown and return like a boomerang, a scythe that slices people right in half, a napalm launcher that sets afire everything in its path, etc. In total, there's over 20 available weapons. You also get a DIY silencer for your shotgun - a kitty cat. Yup, you put the butt of a cat on the barrel of your shotgun to silence it!

Free-roaming is another strongpoint to the game. You can accomplish your daily tasks at your leisure, and run around the open-world to your hearts content. Although you can't expect a map the size of San Andreas, the map is of decent size for the time it was developed and considering it was independently developed. Every building can be explored, and often contains weapons, health, or other goodies.

If you're into modding, you should also enjoy the game. There are tons of mods for POSTAL 2, including plenty on the Steam Workshop. There are tons of weapon mods, a couple of mission" mods
date: and a multiplayer mod (known as Share the Pain
recommended: or STP). One mod in particular I recommend is Eternal Damnation (aka ED)

reviewText: POSTAL 2 is a brilliant game. It has fantastic replay value (I found myself beating the game quite a few times). It's very funny, and whilst the humor may be no longer topical, you have to remember this was originally released in 2003. Nevertheless, it's still funny. The physics in the game are very well done too, especially the ♥♥♥♥ effect. The gore is possibly the most violent and well done in gaming history. The fact that the developers constantly update the game even to this day (the dismemberment feature was originally only in Apocalypse Weekend, and there were a lot fewer weapons in the original release) is astounding. The game does take a while to load each day, but the loading inbetween sections of the town take mere seconds.\n\nOverall, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who's not easily offended or grossed out. It's well worth the money and I can't wait to see what kind of game RWS makes next.

reviewText: POSTAL 2, where do I have to start? Well, let's put it in this way. If you have a annoying bully at school, and you just want to like, chop his head off, POSTAL 2 is great to practice that. Just kidding, but POSTAL 2 is a madness simulator to me, you can basically do everything. You want to fetch with your dog? Done. Are you in for kicking someone's monitor into stuck into a wall? Possible! You want to pee on your ex-wife Melissa? A-Okay!  Do you want to walk on electrical wire at 8 feet high while hoping not to be shocked? Maybe.  You want to steal your neighbour Daniel's taser and taser him to death? Why not? You want to throw a molotov-cocktail at people in a gaybar? Okay, now you've crossed the line. Seriously. So, are you ready for some crazy crap coming up in a small village in Arizona made by some developers which run all the time with scissors in their hands? The game is actually from 2003, but POSTAL 2 is still played by many across the world. Running With Scissors made even a totally new DLC for the game, called POSTAL 2: Paradise Lost, not so long ago, in 2015. I highly recommend this game, and this is one of the best games I've ever played. It's definitely worth your money, especially when it's on sale. And when it's on sale, you should buy Paradise Lost too. Great game. 10/10

reviewText:
A game that up to this moment is continuously supported by it's developers, which are always around to help when any issue pops up.
The world is free for you to explore and roam around. In fact, you'll end up raiding the whole city as you are trying to reach a certain location just because you can.

Every day you get a few errands to complete and multiple ways to do so. Unlike other games, the errands seem to be very simple, some tasks that anyone could face- buying milk, paying a ticket at the police station, get steaks- nothing could go wrong.

The game is as violent as you are, you can either go postal and kill your way out of anything, or try to peacefully make your way out of trouble without getting killed (that's the real challenge).

There are tons of secrets hidden by the map designers that contain either easter eggs and/or hidden weapons and items that will help you as you progress trough the game.

Aside from the fun gameplay, badass one-liners and humorous jokes, the game is not entirely flawless. One of the most stressing features is the loading zones, meaning that whenever you will go around a corner or trough a tunnel you will most likely face a loading screen. The wait time isn't that long, usually taking ~10 seconds, but for a game where traveling is a key feature it starts to get on your nerves pretty quickly. Another flaw is the not-so-great hit reg system, which will cause weapons such as the m4 and m5 to be nearly useless at times, but with an old engine like p2 is running on, the game itself can't be blamed for these.

However, unless you're an actual fan of old games that is used to such issues games used to have, you should probably stay away from it. I just can't get enough.


Just don't forget the Rocky Road.

reviewText: Postal 2  is a first-person shooter video game by Running with Scissors, and it is the sequel to the 1997 game Postal. Both are intentionally highly controversial due to high levels of violence and stereotyping. Unlike its predecessor, Postal 2 is played completely in first-person based on the Unreal Engine. Scenes of the game can be seen in the music video of the Black Eyed Peas single Where Is the Love?".\nIn 2004

reviewText: Postal 2 is the beloved sequel to the game where a guy in a trenchcoat heard voices in his head tell him to murder the entire population with military grade weapons. Having last been committed to a mental asylum, we find the Postal Dude strangely sane with a much more placid view on life. Also, he seems to have married a bossy wife, moved into a trailer in Paradise, AZ gotten a job at a video game design and publishing company (RWS Inc.) and even still has his dog! Way to go, P. Dude! Unfortunately, Paradise seems to be about as stable as the cauldron of chemicals where gunpowder was accidentally invented.\nPostal 2 has a free-roaming environment with goals to be accomplished in no particular order, or even in no specified way. You, the Postal Dude, are given an errand list by your wife each day and must go accomplish your goals, like confessing your sins at church, picking up milk from the store, etc. However, every time you get close to accomplishing these things, something insane happens, like video game protesters raid your job office when you go to pick up your paycheck, or rednecks try to murder you when you buy somebody's favorite Christmas tree (in July). You then get to decide whether you want to be the pacifist and flee the scene, be the hero and fight off the bad guys or be the psycho and murder everyone you see. As RWS Inc. so proudly advertised, the game is only as violent as you are.\nThe graphics in this game are much more polished then the previous game, this time giving us a 3D first person environment to roam around in and a much more accurate targeting system. The music in the game, instead of only being frightening experimental percussion music like the first one, was actually collected from local bands in Tucson, the hometown  of Running With Scissors Inc. Being the sequel, the game also has a much bigger arsenal, ranging from military weapons to a variety of firearms, to many blunt and sharp objects to scissors and so on. The only real problem I have with this game is that nobody seems to be doing the multiplayer when I jump on, but maybe that's just me. Aside from that, if you have a strong stomach and are okay with offensive jokes delivered in a gruesome yet silly way, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Ok... This game... I've played over 500 games before in my life... And not a single one got laughing as hard as this one.

I have a section in my Steam Library called, 'The Holy Game' and Garry's Mod is in there. That's about to change. This game is the best game I have ever played in my life! I love games that keep me laughing, show complete and utter randomness that you forget that there's even a storyline behind it.

Usually in games, I like to do what I'm supposed to do and try not to kill the A.I. this game however, it was just so entertaining to run around killing people with the dumbest sh*t imaginable. I would really like a Postal 2. I don't care about the graphics. In fact, you will end up having so much fun on this game that you will completely forget how bad the graphics are. It's like going back to the original Half Life but now it's actually fun.

The voice acting is hilariously stupid but I love it! Especially the main character's voice. The females on this game make me laugh my a** because they sound like (and I'm pretty sure that they actually were) they were used on 11 year old girls. The males also sound like they were acted by a teenage boy. The main character is just... just... Chuck Testa... And Chuck Norris combined.

This game is so fantastic that it also deserves a list of the pros and cons:

Pros
-Can use cats as gun attatchments
-Can again cop niorety.
-Can be jailed and escape unlike GTA where the cops just kill you
-Can go in nearly every single room in the game.
-Includes drugs
-Steam Workshop
-Variety of Game Modes
-Different story lines
-Killer cats
-Pet dogs
-Different weapons
-Can remove limbs from bodies
-Your drug trip without getting high
-Can get high on cat nip
-Police actually give you a chance to drop your gun unlike you know what
-Police have different guns
-Some civilians supprise you with a gun hidden in there a** crack.
-Can rob a bank unlike you know what
-Can have some good physics unlike you know what
-Can blow up cars and make them go flying
-Can kick people in the face
-Includes Achievements
-Can kick open doors
-Includes zombies
-Can stick sledgehammers up cows a**'s
-Can die by cats
-Can't die from stupid hights like in minecraft
-Can lose limbs and still be alive (unless it's your head).

Cons
-Bad Graphics

Bare in mind that I've only played half of the first day out of seven on only one game mode...

This is my largest review so far and this game deffinately deserves it! Well done to whoever made this, this is the best game I have ever played. I would reccomend this to anyone unless you're some boring fart who just wants to play World Of Warcraft all day.

Overall I would rate this game:

21/10

reviewText:
in postal 2 you play as the son of the faithful mail carrier from the original game
some say this change in character is a negative turn for the story but i think that it's good that RWS is exploring new horizons in character development
if you remember properly Postman Patrick (original protagonist) was a genial, happy-go-lucky man who deeply enjoyed his career
however, Postman Patrick II has a bit of a dark background (being half filipino) but still retains the happy go lucky nature of our beloved patrick I
the gameplay is mostly the same arrow keys to drive truck mouse to throw mail but the addition of brand new enemies such as champ the roving dog makes it a bit more of a challenge than the original game
definitely still a game open for anyone though the new dog petting mechanic appeals to all sorts of casual gamers (i.e. children)
of course i would reccomend this game steam 5/5 best postman simulation out on the market right now (at least until Mail Carrier 2k7 is released!)

reviewText: Postal 2 is definitely in my top 5 games of all time. There are so many features in this game that can strike awe, shock, joy and disgust within the hearts of so many people. It's the one game I will possibly always play. It's been around for about a decade, so there are some limits within the gameplay that can be distractive; Such as loading zones and the character and npc models (you can see their heads being detachable behind their necks.) but personally I'm indifferent to those negative sides. I reccomend this to anyone who likes FPS games, no exceptions (Besides those who regard a game's release date as what makes it good.)

reviewText:
Postal 2 is a diamond in the rough.  It has some problems like hit detection, lots of load screens (on the plus side, they do load fairly quickly) and a mildly annoying warning screen when you first load the game up - Every time.

That being said, this game is just stupid fun.  It seems like every day you come across new weapons, my favourites being the hand axe and the sledgehammer.  The squidgy noise when someones head explodes is insanely satisfying.  You can light people on fire, ♥♥♥♥ on them to put them out, shove the barrel of you gun up a stray cats bumhole, chop off limbs, and use the world as your toilet.

You can also shoot terrorists if you're into playing the role of world police too.  Or if you picked up this game thinking it was your typical FPS and you can't go thirty seconds without shooting someone of a different race in the face.

All in all, Postal 2 is a stupid game that's meant to be stupid and succeeds very well in being just that.

reviewText:
This is a great game for anyone looking to blow off some Steam (pun intended).

Released back in 2003 it still holds up after 12 years, both gameplay and entertainment wise. Postal 2 actually supersedes a lot of current releases when it comes to it's fluid physics for water, gasoline and even ♥♥♥♥.

The Steam version of Postal 2 includes the core game of Postal 2, Postal 2: Share The Pain (The Multiplayer Component), Postal 2: Apocalypse Weekend (an expansion pack for the original Postal 2 released back in 2005 which adds Sunday and Saturday), and finally Postal 2: A Week in Paradise (A mod developed by Resurrection Studios which adds the ability to play through both the core game of Postal 2 and Apocalypse Weekend in one sitting, with additional weapons such as the Chainsaw).

If you want the Eternal Damnation mod you will either have to pick up The Fudge Pack (which also includes Postal 1, and other additional content like game trailers released prior E3), or download it for free and install it as an addon for your Postal 2 Steam Version of the game. This also doesn't include Akella's officially unofficial Штопор Жжот addon released back in 2005.

Share The Pain could USE some (a lot actually) updates, it doesn't seem it has been updated ever since it's release as freeware in 2008; resulting in terrible connection problems, frequent disconnects, and barren list of servers. But Postal 2 is all about the Singleplayer experience, however, a mod or an expension implementing Co-Op would be a long-awaited and a welcome feature, allowing you to play the entire week with your friends would be a blast and add a lot of hours to anyone's playthroughs with additional replayabilty value to it's Singleplayer campaign".

Overall
date: this is a great game and still gives me a massive nostalgia boost."

reviewText:
Its pretty clear why this game got so much grief when it was originally released. I remember some of that and didn't play it back then, cuz, well it wasn't on store shelves that I can remember. Plus it just didn't look that interesting.

Well, finally tried it and I gotta say that it does offend just to offend. To be fair, much of what you see in this game, you find as easter eggs in major titles nowerdays (like GTA, which borrows a lot from Postal).  And of course the whole open world, shot who you want type of thing is GTA's bread and butter.

So, does it work? The game is entertaining and if you can get past the old graphics, its definately worth playing. On all max settings its ok. Gameplay is old-school, but fun.  Has crashed to desktop a bunch of times, which sucks.

Final word, play it to see what the fuss was all about and see if you still think its that offensive. Definately worth picking up when its on sale.

7/10

reviewText:
Postal 2 challenges players to survive a week as The Postal Dude. His week isn't spent behind enemy lines as a guerilla soldier, or fighting off an alien invasion. Postal Dude is spending this week around his own neighborhood, doing mundane errands like cashing his paycheck, buying milk, grabbing some meat for a BBQ, and so on. As it turns out, everyone in Paradise, Arizona is either a jerk, a maniac, a terrorist, or Gary Coleman. On top of that, you're one sandwich short of a six-pack.

To give you an idea of how the average play-through will go. I'll describe one of my misadventures.

-On the way to getting Gary Coleman's autograph, I murdered several people and batted their heads around with a shovel. The police showed up and threw me in prison. They didn't see the murders, but I couldn't suppress the urge to urinate on them.
-Escaping from prison was surprisingly easy. On the way out I scored a police uniform, raided their armory, and...urinated on everyone. I don't have issues, honest!
-I doused a club in gasoline and set everyone on fire. There were a couple survivors, thanks to my quick thinking. After urinating on them to put out the fires, I revived them with the stun gun. They have 4th degree burns though so...hmm.
-Finally I arrived at the mall. There was a long line for Gary's autograph. Instead of waiting I killed someone that just got their book signed. No urinating was involved this time.

This is an open-ended game, and there are always non-violent solutions for every task. In fact you can even complete the game without killing anyone. Taking the easy way out tends to be more fun though. At the very least you'll have to break into a few houses and swipe everyone's kevlar vests, fast food, and crack to keep yourself alive.

Saturday and Sunday make up the expansion portion of the game. This...well..this really isn't good. Every other day is open-ended, there's a sense of exploration, and fun to be had in goofing around. The weekend consists of more traditional FPS levels. They're really linear, and you have to deal with almost constant gun-fights. This gets old very quickly.

Postal 2 is very much a product of its time as well. The jokes are tasteless (says the guy that urinates on burn victims!) and not at all timely. This version adds a bunch of achievements, with most of them being named after memes. Essentially this game was dated when it came out, and dated even more with its re-release. It's still entertaining and hilarious, just be careful who you talk to when you describe the game.
